summary: This document is an email chain from December 2020 discussing the approval process for a victim of Jeffrey Epstein to receive counseling services through the FBI Victim Services Division. It reveals internal FBI procedures and questions regarding victim verification and funding eligibility.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as 'Mr. Epstein', the individual whose actions caused the victim's trauma, prompting her request for therapy.

persons.name: M.S.
persons.context: A licensed mental health counselor certified in sexual abuse trauma, based in Greenacres, Florida, who reached out to the FBI Victim Services Division to begin treatment for a victim.

connections.description: The victim is seeking therapy due to victimization by Jeffrey Epstein.
M.S. is the psychotherapist scheduled to provide treatment to the victim.

events.title: Scheduled Therapy Session
events.description: A therapy session for a victim of Jeffrey Epstein was scheduled to begin.

events.title: Internal FBI Approval Discussion
events.description: FBI Victim Services Division staff exchanged emails questioning the approval process, timing, and funding eligibility for a victim seeking counseling.

keyFacts: The FBI Victim Services Division was processing a request for counseling for a confirmed victim of Jeffrey Epstein in December 2020.
Internal emails show FBI staff questioning why the victim was seeking counseling only at that time and inquiring about her financial situation and other counseling options.
A licensed psychotherapist in Florida was prepared to begin treatment for the victim, pending FBI approval and funding.
The document references a 'victims fund that's now open', indicating the existence of a compensation program for Epstein victims.
The correspondence reveals bureaucratic hurdles and verification processes within the FBI for providing victim services.
